pullRequest.body:
Generalize several hundred type classes throughout Mathlib. This is a large subset of those found by a new linter.

To give some information on how the linter works: it tries to replace a given type class by a parent class. It will accept the generalization if deleting the entire type class causes the theorem to fail to compile. Otherwise, the type class is not being generalized, but can simply be replaced by implicit type class synthesis (or an implicit type class in a `variable` block being pulled in.)

Also see discussion on Zulip here:
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/270676-lean4/topic/Elab.20to.20generalize.20type.20classes.20for.20theorems/near/498862988 https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Elab.20to.20generalize.20type.20classes.20for.20theorems/near/501288855

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+++---+- coe_smul`
`++-- inr_smul`
`++---+ neg`
`+--+ cast_finsupp_sum`
`-+-+ add`
`-+-+ addHom_ext`
`-+-+ mul`
`-+-+ smul`
`-+-+ smul_measure`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
!bench
Good to know, thank you!

Here are the [benchmark results](https://speed.lean-lang.org/mathlib4/run-detail/e5c8b7f7-6fcb-4666-9668-184748bec89d) for commit df3ce3d246a00a94cd35488cc0b4cbf709afffe0.
The entire run failed.
Found no significant differences.

The `lake lint` failures are interesting and I need to investigate more deeply. In particular it appears that in some cases my linter erroneously believes it generalizes a given type class, when what's actually happening is that the original type class is implicitly pulled in instead (and hence the new generalized type class is marked unused)
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](https://speed.lean-lang.org/mathlib4/run-detail/c7655ec0-2ba8-4e95-b506-b055c1c7abfa) for commit b53f84a8b76c54605b3c35b93d714f0f8b4bd231.
There were [significant changes](https://speed.lean-lang.org/mathlib4/compare/bbf30436-8d5a-4680-9b78-5bfcfb145f4f/to/c7655ec0-2ba8-4e95-b506-b055c1c7abfa) against commit 514991a14eea12ccac3a18f4d7bce8f8d4a4ee75:
```diff
  Benchmark                     Metric         Change
  ===================================================
+ ~Mathlib.Algebra.DualNumber   instructions   -28.6%
```

|File|Instructions|%|
|-|-:|:-:|
|`build`|-28.98⬝10⁹|(-0.01%)|
|`Mathlib.Topology.ContinuousMap.StoneWeierstrass`|+1.33⬝10⁹|(+0.50%)|
|`Mathlib.Algebra.Category.CoalgebraCat.ComonEquivalence`|-4.269⬝10⁹|(-5.85%)|
|`Mathlib.Algebra.DualNumber`|-13.481⬝10⁹|(-28.62%)|
[CI run](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13565027714)
Should be probably renamed/moved to match
